body: Quite right. Did you notice if this was borked on PyPI as well? Not currently sure what version is up there.

PyPI updated. Should be good to go. Let me know if not.

Is the problem the assumption of the forward slash in paths? Would this do the trick?

```
-self.coloricon = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'markers/%s.png')
+self.coloricon = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'markers', '%s.png')
```

No, the problem is with backslashes,
Initially the markers were not showing up in Chrome so I used Chrome debugging tool to see the path in the browser and it was;
'C:Anaconda3libsite-packagesgmplotmarkers/000000.png'
Changing all backslashes to slashes makes it work.
The following path is OK:
'C:/Anaconda3/lib/site-packages/gmplot/markers/000000.png'
This is perfect! Thank you

a quick workaround until it is fixed:
(You need to install BeautifulSoup - `pip install beautifulsoup4`)

```
import gmplot

gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter(37.428, -122.145, 16)
gmap.draw("mymap.html")    
# "mymap.html" will NOT open

from bs4 import BeautifulSoup

def insertapikey(fname, apikey):
    """put the google api key in a html file"""
    def putkey(htmltxt, apikey, apistring=None):
        """put the apikey in the htmltxt and return soup"""
        if not apistring:
            apistring = "https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/js?key=%s&callback=initMap"
        soup = BeautifulSoup(htmltxt, 'html.parser')
        body = soup.body
        src = apistring % (apikey, )
        tscript = soup.new_tag("script", src=src, async="defer")
        body.insert(-1, tscript)
        return soup
    htmltxt = open(fname, 'r').read()
    soup = putkey(htmltxt, apikey)
    newtxt = soup.prettify()
    open(fname, 'w').write(newtxt)

insertapikey("mymap.html", apikey)
# "mymap.html" will open
```

I wrote this because I needed it right now :-)
hm? i can import gmplot with python 3.5 just fine, and nowhere in the code that module is used - what is exactly your issue here?

Thanks for responding so quickly. Interesting. I pip installed gmplot and
kept getting this error. I think googlemaps has to be accessed through
Client now.
Once I installed Google API Client for Python and imported it, the error
went away.

GoogleMapPlotter is a class defined by gmplot itself: https://github.com/vgm64/gmplot/blob/master/gmplot/gmplot.py#L16 and it has nothing to do with how you access GMaps (infact, gmplot does _not_ access google maps in any way, it just creates an html page, which is the one doing the access

i suspect there;s something else broken on your installation

Nothing broken on my end and, well, you are using googleapis. I did this
last night in a different virtualenv and it worked (below). It may be a
problem with pip version, or the fact that I have a Google Maps key  and it
has to go through Client. So it may be an authorization issue...for those
with an API key

please check gmplot code again, unless you're using geocode() (which is highly unlikely during import) no part of the code is accessing googleapis. there is some misconfiguration on your side, as just importing a module without doing anything with you (as your PR does) looks fishy and signal of another underlying problem with your installation more than something in gmpplot

particularly soon. Feel free to poke me about it again if I haven't done
anything in a few weeks.

Michael Woods

Change the following line
self.coloricon = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(**file**), 'markers/%s.png')
 in the class init definition to
self.coloricon = "http://www.googlemapsmarkers.com/v1/%s/"
Looks like a good solution - also gets around the issues that the created file only works when opened on the machine it was generated from.
The "ImportError: cannot import name 'GoogleMapPlotter'" error was fixed in master, but was never pushed to pypi. v1.1.1 should alleviate the import error, no Client import required.

Thanks!

Hi, I am having trouble displaying the "contents" in the InfoWindow.

## 

gmap = gmplot.GoogleMapPlotter(37.428, -122.145, 15)
gmap.marker(37.428, -122.145, 'r')
contents = "show content"
gmap.infowindow(contents, 37.428, -122.14)

## gmap.draw('map.html')

I can see an InfoWindow but no contents.
What am I doing wrong here?

Thanks.

you have to make the content of `contents` a string, so

```
contents = "'show content'"
```

(note the additional quotes araund show content), anyway it doesnt look like this will be merged anytime soon
Ah, thank you for the explanation!
that's in a pr not merged/commented yet : https://github.com/vgm64/gmplot/pull/15 (but feel free to use that code and report if it works as you'd expect)
